page.title: 01Stowe & District
page.content: Stowe village is in that part of Shropshire designated an area of outstanding natural beauty. It is in a landscape of steeply wooded hills, narrow valleys with streams, interspersed with small fields of arable and pasture for sheep and cattle. The village contains a church, farm and a handful of houses. The rest of the area consists of isolated hill farms. Forestry and farming provide employment for a few, the remainder having to find work outside the area. There is no public transport, though the Heart of Wales railway passes through the Teme valley in the south, with the nearest station at Knighton 3 Km away. The summit of Stowe Hill is marked by a survey point 427m, and 1Km to the north stands the ancient British hill fort of Caer Caradoc.
